preface.simpara: The guide describes the features of Red Hat OpenShift.io. It also contains information about potential problems users may encounter while using the software. Where possible, workarounds are described for identified issues.

chapter.title: Introduction to Red Hat OpenShift.io
chapter.simpara: Red Hat Developer Program offers a Software as a Service (SaaS) product for developers called Red Hat OpenShift.io to meet your software development requirements.

This section introduces Red Hat OpenShift.io and provides an overview of the main features of the product. Read it to understand the benefits of using OpenShift.io and to learn about how organizations and developers can use it for their everyday tasks.

section.title: Red Hat OpenShift.io Overview
section.simpara: Red Hat OpenShift.io is a highly collaborative open-source, web-based application life cycle management (ALM) solution. It is a next-generation product for developers to manage the development life cycle with one efficient tool.

section.title: Features
section.simpara: OpenShift.io offers features to seamlessly manage end-to-end application development. Members of distributed teams can use it to perform the following tasks without leaving the browser window:

listitem.simpara: Project planning and issue tracking using your choice of Agile methodology.
Automating project releases.
Creating development environments and testing based on requirements.
Coding using an integrated development environment based on Eclipse Che, which provides a workspace for developing your application.
Development in this context-aware environment provides the appropriate context for the developer and project, such as which branch, repository, language, and files are referenced.
Interacting with integrated GitHub repositories.
Compiling and reviewing code in Pull Requests as required.
Use the QuickStart wizards to create basic applications with their own new repo on GitHub, a build pipeline integrated with Jenkins, and a related new OpenShift project.
Using migration wizards to migrate legacy J2EE applications to the cloud.
Building, testing, deploying, and monitoring codebases using Continuous Integration pipelines that can be tailored to the requirements of a team or an individual.
Deploying applications packaged as a set of containers to OpenShift, which powers the underlying services such as the Eclipse Che workspaces and Pipelines.
Using integrated but customizable Jenkins build pipelines to facilitate rapid testing and environment promotion.
Use the full-stack analysis feature on your project open source components to identify potential security issues and recommend safer alternative components or component versions to use instead.

Use the self-learning analytics engine to improve the code quality and make data-based choices. The engine scans community libraries, security vulnerabilities, and other GitHub metrics to provide useful real-time assistance for developers that learns and improves over time.

section.title: Registration and Early Access
section.simpara: Currently, OpenShift.io is available for a limited early access program. In the OpenShift.io home page, click Sign up for the Preview to join a waiting list for Early Access. You will receive an email informing you when you have been given access to use the system.

section.title: Support
section.simpara: Red Hat currently does not offer a support subscription for OpenShift.io. The service is available as a free Developer Preview for open-source projects and developers.

section.title: Related Information
section.simpara: See also the following related Red Hat resources related to the Red Hat Developer Program:

chapter.title: Accessing Red Hat OpenShift.io
chapter.simpara: This section explains how to register and gain access to Red Hat OpenShift.io. It also outlines how to log in to and log out of the service.

section.title: Signing up for the Red Hat Developers Program
section.simpara: To start using Red Hat OpenShift.io, create a new Red Hat Developers (RHD) account or use an existing RHD or social media account.

important.simpara: Early access to the service is limited and will be allocated as resources become available. When you sign up, you are added to a waiting list. You are notified when access to the system is available.

listitem.simpara: Navigate to Red Hat OpenShift.io.
Click Sign Up For The Preview. You can register using an existing social or Red Hat account.
To register a new Red Hat account:
At the Red Hat OpenShift.io Developer Preview page, click Register.
Enter your name, email address, company, and password in the appropriate fields.
Select the terms and conditions check boxes.
Click Create my account.
Verify your email address to complete registration.
To register using your existing Red Hat account or a social account from services such as JBoss Developer, GitHub, Stack Overflow, LinkedIn, Twitter, Facebook, Google, or Microsoft:
Click the appropriate social account button.
Add your login credentials for the selected service and authorize the creation of the account.

section.title: Related Information
section.simpara: The following links provide additional resources about accessing Red Hat’s offering for developers:

simpara.link: Red Hat Enterprise Linux Developer Suite
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Developer Workstation
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Developer Support

listitem.simpara: Ensure that you have registered for a Red Hat Developer Program account.
Navigate to the Red Hat OpenShift.io website in a browser window.
Click Log In at the top of the OpenShift.io main page.
Log in either manually (with your Red Hat Developers account) or using a social account:
Log in using your Red Hat account:
Enter your email address or Red Hat Developers Login ID and password.
Click Log In.
Log in using a social account:
Click the appropriate social account button from the listed options.
Follow the instructions to allow the social account to log in.

If asked, add information about yourself on the Additional Action Required page. If the provided email address already has an account, an option to link your social account with your Red Hat Developers account is available. An email arrives in the account to confirm linking the two accounts.
Select the check boxes to indicate agreement with the terms and conditions if required and click Submit.

section.title: Logging out of Red Hat OpenShift.io

listitem.simpara: Ensure that you have logged in to the Red Hat OpenShift.io website.
Click your name in the top right corner of the application. If the current page does not show the profile menu, navigate to the main page at Red Hat OpenShift.io.
In the drop-down menu, click the Log Out option.

section.title: About spaces
section.simpara: Spaces are the equivalent of projects. Each Iteration and Work Item must be attached to a space, and a team of users can be assigned to a space for the appropriate roles. By default, a space contains one or more Areas and Iterations.

section.title: Creating a new space
section.simpara: To start working with a new project, create a new space. Each space includes a team of users in assigned roles as well as unique Work Items and Iterations used to manage the new project.

listitem.simpara: Ensure that you have logged in to Red Hat OpenShift.io.
On your Red Hat OpenShift.io home page, click your user name in the upper-left corner of the screen.
Select Create space from the drop-down menu.
In the Name field, add a unique name for the new space.

From the Template drop-down list, select Scenario Driven Planning. This template creates spaces based on Scenarios, which are real-world problems from the user’s point of view. The Scenarios deliver Value Propositions and are realized through (user) Experiences.
Click Create to create your new space. The How would you like to get started? dialog box displays the following options:
Import existing code: Import existing code into the new space and set up a continuous integration (CI) pipeline using OpenShift Online and Jenkins.
Create a new Quickstart project: Use wizards to automatically set up your development environment and quickly create projects by using the desired tools.
No thanks, take me to the new space dashboard: Go to your new space dashboard to begin working in the space.

section.title: Deleting an existing space
section.simpara: If an OpenShift.io space is no longer required, delete it as follows:

warning.simpara: When deleted, the space and all its contents (Work Items, Codebases, Workspaces, etc.) are also permanently deleted.

listitem.simpara: On your Red Hat OpenShift.io home page, click your user name in the upper-left corner of the screen.
On the drop-down list, click View all spaces.
Click the (image:delete.png [Delete]) icon, the Remove Space dialog box is displayed asking for confirmation.
Click Remove to confirm and delete your space.

section.title: Configuring a codebase
section.simpara: After creating a space, you can add a codebase from GitHub and set up a pipeline to build the code.

listitem.simpara: Create a space. See for instructions.
Click Analyze at the top of the screen to view the dashboard for your space.
The Codebases section displays the following options:
If you already have codebases in your space, they are listed and you can use the + icon at the upper-right of the section to import more codebases.
If there are no codebases in your space, you can:
use Add Codebase to manually add a codebase.
use Import Codebase to add an existing codebase.
Click Add Codebase.
In the How would you like to get started? dialog box, select one of the following options:

textobject.phrase: How would you like to get started menu

section.title: Importing existing code
section.simpara: Use the OpenShift.io Application wizard to import an existing project codebase into OpenShift.io.

listitem.simpara: In the GitHub Organization section, select your organization name from the Organization drop-down list. For this example, use the organization name assigned to your personal GitHub account.
Click Next.
In the GitHub Repositories section, select the repository to import into OpenShift.io from the Repository Name Pattern list, and then click Next.
In the Configure Pipeline section:
Select a build pipeline strategy. The default value Release, Stage, Approve and Promote is suitable for most use cases.
Ensure that the Override Jenkins and POM files option is selected
Click Next.
In the Build configuration section the Jenkins space field displays the name of your Jenkins space.
Select Trigger build to trigger a build once your Application is deployed.
Select Add continuous integration web hooks to add continuous integration web hooks to your Application.
Use the default options for these fields.
Click Finish.
The Summary section displays your selected options for the Application. Click Ok to continue.

section.title: Creating a new quickstart project
section.simpara: Use the OpenShift.io Quickstart project wizard to create a new project from the available templates.

listitem.simpara: In the Select Stack section, use the drop-down menu or click one of the displayed technology stack icons to select a project type and click Next.
In the Define Project section:

Select your organization from the Organization drop-down list. The drop-down lists the GitHub organizations where you are a member. A new repository for the Quickstart project will be created in the selected organization.
In the OpenShift Project Name field, type a unique name for your project.
Keep the default value for the Group Id and Version fields.
Click Next.
In the Configure Pipeline section, select a build pipeline strategy. The default value Release, Stage, Approve and Promote is suitable for most use cases.
Click Next.

The Build configuration section displays the name of your Jenkins space and options to Trigger build and Add continuous integration web hooks when your application is deployed. Use the default options for these fields and click Finish.
The Summary section displays your selected options for the Application. Click Ok to continue.

section.title: Importing a codebase
section.simpara: Use the Import Codebase option to manually add the details for your existing codebase into OpenShift.io.

listitem.simpara: Click Import Codebase.
If required, in the Space Path field, change the path to your space.
In the GitHub Repository field, add the GitHub repository path.
Click Sync to retrieve details for the repository. If the sync is successful, metadata for the added repository is displayed under the Sync button.
Click Associate Repository to Space to add the repository to your space. The Create Codebases sub-tab now displays your repository with information about when it was created and the last commit date.
Click Create workspace for the target repository from the displayed list. A success message appears when the Workspace is successfully created in Eclipse Che.
When your Workspace is ready, in the drop-down list, select the new Workspace for your repository, and then click Open.
A new browser tab loads and displays the Eclipse Che Workspace with your repository codebase.

note.simpara: In case a new Workspace is not created, check and ensure that your browser allows pop-up windows from this page.

section.title: About Collaborators
section.simpara: Collaborators are members assigned to particular Work Items within a space. They are assigned tasks for the development project which are tracked using Work Items. You can add Collaborators to your space and then assign the relevant Work Items to them.

section.title: Adding Collaborators
section.simpara: You can add users as Collaborators to a space and then assign Work Items to each person.

listitem.simpara: Create a new space or select an existing space.
Ensure that the target user has an OpenShift.io account.
From your OpenShift.io dashboard, click the name of a space to view its dashboard.
Click Collaborators.
Click the blue plus (+) icon in the top right corner. The Add collaborators dialog box displays.
Click Select and type a name in the text box to search for a user.
From the displayed results, select the name of one or multiple users to add as Collaborators for your space.
Click Add to add the selected users as collaborators.

section.title: Viewing and changing collaborators
section.simpara: After adding collaborators, you can view their details or remove them from your space.

listitem.simpara: Log in to Red Hat OpenShift.io with a valid user account. See .
Create a new space or select an existing space.
Ensure you have added collaborators to your space.
Click the Collaborators tab.
From the displayed list of collaborators on the Collaborators page, click the three dots next to the collaborator name.
Either:
Select View user to view the collaborator details.
Select Remove from space to remove them from the space.

section.title: Assigning a collaborator
section.simpara: After adding Collaborators to your space, you can assign Work Items to them:

listitem.simpara: Ensure that the user is added as a Collaborator to your space.
Click the Plan tab to view a list of Work Items for your space.
Double-click a Work Item to view its details.
Click the Assignee text box for a drop-down search window. Type the name of a Collaborator in your space to assign them to this Work Item.

section.title: About Work Items
section.simpara: Work Items (WI) are trackable and measurable units of work within a space. They are captured representations of work, and can be modified based on the requirements of the development project.

Users can create and manage Work Items within a space using the Planner. Work Items track data such as ideas, user stories, bugs, and tasks. Work Items can be grouped and categorized into Areas and Iterations to track progress and plan work.

Work Items are assigned to users and their status is changed to indicate the progress of the Work Item. Link Work Items to each other based on their relationships, enabling users to plan the scope of work better. For example, you can link Work Item A as the parent of Work Item B, enabling you to prioritize and order your work.

The Planner includes a set of predefined templates based on common planning methodologies such as Scrum, Agile, and Scenario Driven Development. These templates determine the structure and features of the included Work Item types and states that are available for a space.

section.title: Creating a new Work Item
section.simpara: You can add Work Items to your space in one of several ways.

listitem.simpara: Create a new space or select an existing space.

section.title: Quick-Add a New Work Item
section.simpara: You can use the quick-add method as an instant widget to add Work Items to your space:

listitem.simpara: Click Plan to view the Planner for your space.
Either use the default Backlog view:
Click Create Work Item at the bottom of the page.
Add a title and description in the displayed fields.
Click ✓ to create the Work Item.
Or click Board for the Board view:
In the new column, click +.
In the displayed fields, select a Work Item type, add a title, and add a description for your new Work Item.
Click ✓ to create the Work Item.

section.title: Using the Backlog to Create a Work Item

listitem.simpara: Click Plan in your space.
Click Backlog to view the Work Item backlog.
Click Create.
Click the desired Work Item Type symbol.
Add the title, Area, Iteration, Label, and Description for your new Work Item.
Individually click ✓ to save the changes for each field.
Click X at the top right corner of the screen after saving all changes.

section.simpara: The new Work Item now displays in the Backlog view.

section.title: Using the Detailed Method to Create Work Items
section.simpara: The detailed method requires adding more details for the Work Item compared to the quick-add method, which only requires basic information to create the Work Item.

listitem.simpara: Click Analyze to view the space dashboard.
In the My Work Items panel, click +.
Click the desired Work Item type.
In the new Work Item form:
Add a title for the Work Item and click ✓ or press Enter to save the new Work Item. This creates a new Work Item. You must save each of the subsequent changes to fields individually.
Assign the Work Item to a Collaborator in the Assignees field. The assignee field for a new Work Item is empty as a default.

Assign an Area to the Work Item from the Area field drop-down list and click ✓ to save the change. By default, the name of your workspace is set as the Root Area and is displayed as one of the options in the drop-down list.

Assign a relevant Iteration to the Work Item from the Iteration drop-down list and click ✓ to save. By default, the name of your workspace is set as the Root Iteration and is displayed as one of the options in the drop-down list.
Click Add label to add existing or new labels to your Work Item.
Add a description for the Work Item in the Edit Text field and click ✓ to save.
Optionally, expand the Total links option to link to other related Work Items as follows:
Click the Create Link button.
Use the Select Link Type drop-down menu to select the appropriate relationship between the current and new Work Item.
Start typing the title or ID of a Work Item in the Search for work items field. Select one of the listed suggestions.
Click Link to save the relationship.
Optionally, expand the Comments option to add or see comments for your Work Item. Users can edit or delete their own comments.
To close the new Work Item panel:
Ensure that all your changes are individually saved.
Click x at the top of the panel.

section.title: Working with an Existing Work Item
section.simpara: Click Plan to use the Planner to track your Work Items and Iterations using either the list view or the board view. The Planner contains two views:

listitem.simpara: The Backlog is the default Planner view. This view displays all Work Items in a flat or hierarchal view organized by Iterations and type. This view lists the active and future Iterations and their Work Items.

Click Board to see Work Items in a Kanban-based view. Each Work Item appears in the appropriate column depending on its current status. You can edit Work Items in this view and drag and drop them in the appropriate status column.

section.simpara: Use the Planner to change the attributes of a Work Item, associate them with Iterations, update their progress, and filter them according to your requirements.

section.title: Modifying an existing work item
section.simpara: You can modify the following Work Item attributes:

listitem.simpara: Status
Owner
Area
Iteration
Label
Description
Relations with other Work Items
Comments

section.simpara: See for more information on modifying the above attributes.

section.title: Associating Work Items with an Iteration
section.simpara: To associate a Work Item with an Iteration:

listitem.simpara: Click Plan to see the Planner for your space.
From the displayed options, select Associate with Iteration. The Associate with Iteration dialog box appears and displays which Iteration, if any, the Work Item is associated with.
From the drop-down list, select an Iteration for your Work Item.
Click Reassociate.

section.simpara: The Work Item is now associated with the selected Iteration.

section.title: Ordering and Monitoring Work Items
section.simpara: The Backlog displays a list view used to plan your work. You can order Work Items based on their priority, status, and other parameters to organize them.
The Backlog displays the list of Work Items as a list where all the Work Items display in a single file.
Click Plan to view the Planner. You can order the Work Items in your space as follows:

The Board view displays a visual representation of your Work Item progress. Based on their status, the Work Items are sorted into the new, open, in progress, resolved, or closed columns. Use this feature to track and update the status of Work Items as you progress through your task list.
In the Board view, you can drag and drop the selected Work Item to the relevant column based on the progress of the Work Item.

section.title: Filtering Work Items
section.simpara: Filter your Work Item view in the Planner as follows:

listitem.simpara: Click Plan and then click either Backlog or Board.
Use the Select drop-down menu to select a Work Item attribute.
Click the text box next to the Select option. This displays a list of potential filters.
You can filter Work Items by Assignee, Creator, Area, State, and Label. Select the appropriate option from the drop down menu. The text box displays a list of valid options for the selected field.
Select the appropriate option to filter the Work Items.

section.title: About areas
section.simpara: Areas can organize related Work Items into groups to distinguish between different types or functionalities that are worked on within a space.
A space can also include areas. As an example, your space represents your software project, and each area tracks components attached to the space.
Each area can have child areas which represent the sub-components for your software project.

section.title: Creating a New Area
section.simpara: You can create a new child Area to group together related Work Items by type or functionality. When you create a new space, OpenShift.io automatically creates a root Area with the same name. Each additional Area within the space is created as a child of the root Area or another existing Area in the space.

listitem.simpara: Ensure you have created a space to use.
In the top right corner of the Areas view, click + Add Areas.
In the Add New Area dialog box, add a name for your new Area and a parent Area.
Click Create to create the new child area.

section.title: Assigning an Area to a Work Item
section.simpara: You can group Work Items by type or functionality by assigning relevant Areas to the Work Items as follows:

listitem.simpara: Ensure that the user is added as a collaborator to your space.
Ensure that you have created a Work Item for the space.
Click the Plan tab to view a list of Work Items for your space.
Double-click a Work Item to view its details.
Click the Area field to view a list of Areas to assign to the space. By default, your Root Area is assigned to a new Work Item.
Select one of the existing Areas to assign to your Work Item.
Click the check box to confirm the name of the Area.

section.title: About Iterations
section.simpara: Use Iterations to organize Work Items to plan and implement tasks for a development project. When used with Scrum, Iterations can be utilized to model Sprints.

You can use the Planner to map your Work Items to Iterations to plan your work based on your project requirements. It enables you to set time-specific goals by grouping priority Work Items into a single development cycle. It also helps you track your progress for each Iteration and compare it with past Iterations and associated Work Items.

section.title: Creating a new iteration
section.simpara: Add iterations to your space to plan and organize your Work Items. Click Plan to view and modify existing Iterations and to add new Iterations.

listitem.simpara: Ensure you have created a space.
Click Plan to view the Planner.
Click + next to the All Iterations option.
Enter a Name for your new Iteration.
Optionally, create a parent-child link by selecting the parent Iteration from the Parent Iteration drop-down list.
Add a Description for the new Iteration.
Add a Start Date and End Date for your new Iteration.
Toggle the Force Active switch to ON to force start the Iteration.
Click Create to create the new Iteration.

section.simpara: Your new Iteration appears under All Iterations. If you selected the Force Active option, your Iteration has started and appears under Active Iteration.

section.title: Selecting an Iteration
section.simpara: After logging in and selecting the appropriate space, click Plan to view the Iterations for that space. Existing Iterations are grouped into one of the following categories:

listitem.simpara: Active Iteration lists active Iterations.
All Iterations displays a list of all Iterations in the space. These include active and closed Iterations, as well as Iterations that have not yet started.

section.simpara: Select an Iteration listed in one of these groups to display the included Work Items. See Associating Work Items with an Iteration for more information.

section.title: All Iterations
section.simpara: After creating an Iteration, the new Iteration displays in the All Iterations view.

listitem.simpara: Select Edit to change the Iteration details.
Select Close to end your Iteration.
Select Create Child to create a child Iteration for the target Iteration.

section.title: Active Iteration
section.simpara: When an Iteration starts, it is added to the Active Iteration list. The Active Iteration list displays:

listitem.simpara: The start and end dates for the Iteration.
A tracker to track the Iteration status based on the completion of the Work Items associated with it.
The description of the Iteration.

section.simpara: To end an Iteration:

listitem.simpara: In the dialog box, click Close.

section.title: About Pipelines
section.simpara: Pipelines are a continuous delivery system that test and deploy the code at each step to provide feedback to the user. Examples of such steps are unit testing, performance, integration, and deployment. Each step of the pipeline implements a different level of testing and deployment tasks, provides results, and then passes the code on to the next step.
In OpenShift.io, you configure a pipeline build when creating or importing a project. The pipeline build is triggered when a Collaborator commits a change to the code repository.

section.title: Creating a new pipeline
section.simpara: To create a new pipeline for your space, you must add a new project to the space. OpenShift.io includes templates to add new projects to your space.

listitem.simpara: Ensure that you have created a space to use for the pipeline. See for instructions.
Click the name of a space to view the dashboard.
Click Add to space. The How would you like to get started? menu appears for your new space.

textobject.phrase: How would you like to get started menu

listitem.simpara: Click Create a new Quickstart project.
In the first step of the Application Wizard:
Select a Technology Stack from the listed tiles.
Click Next.
From the options in the Organisation field, select an organization. For this example, use the organization name assigned to your personal GitHub account.
In the OpenShift Project Name field, add a unique name for your project.
Leave the default value for the Group Id and Version fields and click Next.
Select a build pipeline strategy. For this example, use the default value (Release, Stage, Approve and Promote) and click Next.
The Build configuration screen displays the details for your Jenkins space and options for web hooks and triggering builds. Use the default options for these fields and click Finish.

section.simpara: You have now added a Quickstart project to your space, which initiates a build pipeline for your new project. At this stage, OpenShift.io also adds your project pipeline into your OpenShift Online account and creates a new GitHub repository for your project.
A confirmation screen appears, which includes a Git repositories link. Use this link to view your new project GitHub repository.

section.title: Staging a Pipeline
section.simpara: In a build pipeline, Stage and Run are individual OpenShift projects. Stage is a production staging area to review and test changes before they are finalized and staged on Run.
The new build pipeline pushes version 1.0.1 of your new project into Stage and then, after user approval, to Run.
Optionally, view the build pipeline details in OpenShift Online:

listitem.simpara: In the Pipeline page, click Build #1 for the build pipeline in progress.
When redirected, log into your OpenShift Online account.
Click View Log to view the Jenkins instance logs.

textobject.phrase: A Running Pipeline Build in OpenShift Online

section.title: Configuring Pipelines
section.simpara: Advanced users can change the settings for their project pipeline builds in OpenShift Online. For most users, we do not recommend changing the default values OpenShift.io sets up.

listitem.simpara: Ensure that you have created a build pipeline for your project. See for instructions.
Navigate to your space dashboard.
Click Create.
Click Pipelines. The Pipelines page lists all the pipeline builds for your project.
Click Edit Pipeline for the target pipeline build.
Enter your OpenShift Online credentials when prompted. When successful, you are redirected to your OpenShift Online account Console.

warning.simpara: OpenShift.io sets up the required default options for your pipeline build. We do not recommended changing these default settings.

listitem.simpara: In this page, you can edit the following attributes for your build pipelines:
Use the Source Configuration section to edit your project Git Repository URL.
Use the Jenkinsfile Type option to select the source of your Jenkinsfile for the build.
Use the Jenkinsfile Source Path option to provide a relative path to your Jenkinsfile.
When ready, click Save to save your changes.

section.title: Viewing the Pipeline Projects in OpenShift Online
section.simpara: To view the OpenShift Online projects that support your project pipeline, navigate to console.starter-us-east-2.openshift.com. This page displays the following projects (or namespaces) that are created in OpenShift Online:

listitem.simpara: The username project is where your pipelines run. This project name is your OpenShift Online user name.
The username-che project is for your Che Host and workspaces.
The username-jenkins project runs your Jenkins Master or your Jenkins Slaves. Click Monitoring after clicking this project to access your Jenkins console.

The username-stage project is for your personal use. In this project, pods display as running or previously run pipelines. For maintenance, click this project and power down individual pods as required.
The username-run project is identical to the username-stage project and is an environment for experimenting with your OpenShift pods.

section.title: About Stack Reports
section.simpara: OpenShift.io analyzes the health of your entire stack and its component libraries and provides recommendations to help you use relevant application components for your stack in the form of a stack report. The stack report enables you to make informed decisions on the choice of open source components, augment your development stack, and reduce the risk to your organization.
The OpenShift.io analytics stack report provides you information about:

listitem.simpara: The components comprising your stack
Security issues and version incompatibilities
Popularity of the components used in the stack
The purpose or tags associated with the components
License conflicts at the stack and component level
Outlier application components in your stack

section.simpara: Based on the analyses it recommends:

listitem.simpara: Additional application components that match or better suit your stack by comparing with similar stacks.
Alternative components to replace existing components in case of license conflicts, security issues, compatibility with the rest of your stack, and so on.

section.simpara: Based on these recommendations, you can create work items and follow through in the Planner to update your stack as required.

section.title: Using your Stack Report
section.simpara: OpenShift.io Analytics helps you make informed choices with respect to your development stack and its component libraries by analyzing your stack at the development stage, within your IDE, and at the deployment stage.

section.title: Development Stage
section.simpara: OpenShift.io Analytics analyzes your stack at the development stage and flags components with security vulnerabilities in your Che workspace. It also recommends a secure, alternate version for your stack.

formalpara.title: Prerequisite
formalpara.para: Ensure that you use Che workspace to develop an application.

formalpara.title: Procedure
formalpara.para: You can access inputs from OpenShift.io Analytics within the Che IDE as follows:

listitem.simpara: Mouse hover the flagged component to see the CVE for the flagged component and the recommended alternate version.
Update the component to the recommended version.

section.title: Deployment Stage
section.simpara: At the Deployment stage, OpenShift.io Analytics analyzes your stack and provides a detailed stack analysis report. It analyzes various parameters of your stack components and recommends alternative and additional components suitable for your stack.

formalpara.title: Prerequisites
formalpara.para: Ensure that you deploy your project and create a build pipeline for your project.

listitem.simpara: In the Stack Report Recommendations section of your space dashboard, click Show complete stack report to access the detailed stack report for your manifest files.

section.simpara: Alternatively, you can access your stack report as follows:

listitem.simpara: Click Create and then Pipelines to view the pipeline builds for your project.
Click Stack Report to see the stack and component level analyses for your project.
The report displays:
Stack report: A synopsis of the stack’s analysis report.

Detail analysis of your stack components: A list of all the stack components and their various parameters, including recommendations of alternate components in case of license outliers or usage outliers.
Additional components recommended by OpenShift.io: A list of additional components commonly used by similar stacks.
See section for further details.

Note that OpenShift.io recommends Alternate Components for your stack if it identifies license or usage outliers.

In the Action column adjacent to the recommended alternate or additional components, click Create Work Item to create a work item in the OpenShift.io Planner and follow through on the recommendations.

section.title: Interpreting your stack report
section.simpara: The OpenShift.io analytics report comprises three components:

section.title: Stack summary
section.simpara: The Stack summary provides a synopsis of the analysis report.
It displays:

listitem.simpara: OpenShift.io analytics examines Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) of the components in the stack and highlights vulnerabilities, if any.

OpenShift.io analytics analyzes your overall stack composition, compares it to other similar stacks, and displays the number of components in your stack that are not commonly used in similar stacks or that rarely go together.
OpenShift.io analytics analyzes the licenses used in your stack, and displays the number of unknown licenses. It also displays the number of license conflicts in your stack.

section.title: Detailed analysis of your stack components
section.simpara: The detailed component analysis helps you assess the credibility of your stack components.
It provides recommendations for relevant alternate components by analyzing all the components in the stack and their parameters such as:

listitem.simpara: The detailed analysis report lists current, recommended, and latest available versions of the components in your stack, so that you can select a suitable version for your stack.

Based on the CVEs of the stack components, OpenShift.io Analytics identifies security vulnerabilities in your stack components. The CVE scores are displayed when you move the mouse pointer over components identified with security vulnerabilities.
The detailed analysis report lists licenses for each component, flags unknown and conflicting licenses, and recommends Alternate Components in case of License Outliers.
The detailed analysis report tracks the number of projects in OpenShift.io that use the same component. It recommends Alternate Components in case of Usage Outliers.
OpenShift.io analytics tracks GitHub statistics, such as Usage Count and number of Watchers for the components of your stack.
The detailed analysis report lists all the projects dependent on this component.
The detailed analysis report lists the tags associated with the components of your stack.

section.simpara: You can filter the detailed component analysis report to highlight:

section.title: Additional components recommended by OpenShift.io
section.simpara: OpenShift.io recommends additional components suitable for your stack based on its analysis of similar open source stacks. These components are commonly used by similar stacks and augment your stack. It also displays various parameters relevant to the components, so that you can assess their credibility and make informed choices on adding them to your stack.
To add the recommended component to your stack, click Create work item adjacent to the recommended alternate or additional component.

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.simpara: This glossary provides concise definitions of terms and explanations of concepts used in Red Hat OpenShift.io and in related documentation.

listitem.simpara: Use Areas to organize Work Items to distinguish between different types or functionalities that are being worked on within a space.
A Backlog is a list of Work Items that have not been triaged and assigned to a specific Iteration.

A space is the equivalent of a project. Each Iteration and Work Item must be attached to a space, and a team of people can be attached to a space in various roles. By default, a space contains at least one Area and one Iteration.

Iterations are used to organize Work Items for planning or implementation in a certain order. They are time bound and can be used to model Sprints when used with Scrum. Typically an Iteration comprises a mix of work items, ranging from Scenarios, Features, Papercuts, Experiences or Tasks, identified to be executed within the time frame of the Iteration.

Pipelines are a continuous delivery system that, at each step, tests and deploys the code to provide feedback to the user. Examples of such steps are unit testing, performance, integration, and deployment. Each step of the pipeline implements different levels of testing and deployment tasks, provides results, and then passes the code on to the next step.

A software development methodology focused on real-world problems, or Scenarios, described in the language and from the viewpoint of the user. Scenarios deliver particular Value Propositions and are realized through Experiences.

Work Items describe and keep track of work that needs to be completed. They can be assigned to collaborators within a space. Each Work Item must be attached to a space and an Area (assigned by default). This can be used to model bugs, tasks, features, ideas, and more.
Components of your software stack that are not commonly used in similar open source stacks or that rarely go together.
OpenShift.io analyzes the CVEs of all your components and flags components that have security vulnerabilities.
Licenses in your stack that are not commonly used in similar stacks or that rarely go together.
Components recommended by OpenShift.io to replace license or usage outliers.
Licenses unknown to OpenShift.io.
Licenses that conflict at the stack or component level.
Workspaces are fully configured web-based development environments suitable for your code and runtime needs. They are runtime environments where you can modify, test, debug, or run your code.
